quote: Lynne Ramsay is a genius. This film just destroys me every single time. The way she photographs childhood, the grime and the beauty of it simultaneously -- there's nobody else who does that.

I mean, In the Mood for Love -- I think this is maybe the most beautiful film ever made. Every single frame. Wong Kar-wai and Christopher Doyle, what they do with color and longing. It changed the way I think about what cinema can express.
Rashomon. Yeah, everyone should see this. It invented an entire way of telling stories. You can trace so much of modern cinema back to what Kurosawa did here.
Fanny and Alexander is one of those films where you sit down and five hours later you look up and you can't believe it's over. Bergman at his most generous and warm.
Spike Lee, man. Do the Right Thing. This is maybe the most important American film of the last fifty years. It's still as urgent now as it was in 1989.
This is the film that made me want to make films. Seven Samurai -- every time I watch it, I find something new. The construction of the final battle is the most extraordinary thing in cinema.
Tarkovsky is God. Stalker is a religious experience. You don't watch it, you submit to it. The zone is the most incredible space ever created in cinema.

Spirit of the Beehive -- Victor Erice made maybe the greatest film about childhood. The way Ana watches Frankenstein for the first time and the world is never the same. I feel that every time I watch a great film.
Cronenberg is one of the true originals. Videodrome predicted everything about our relationship with screens. Long live the new flesh!

The 400 Blows is the reason I make movies. That final freeze frame -- Antoine running to the ocean. It's the most heartbreaking and hopeful image in all of cinema. Truffaut understood something about the restlessness of being young.
Agnes Varda -- Cleo from 5 to 7. I love everything about this movie. It's about time and waiting and being alive in a city. She makes Paris feel like it's breathing.
Persona is one of those films that I come back to again and again. It's about performance, identity, what it means to be a woman -- Bergman gets at something that I don't think anyone else has.
I'll take Fanny and Alexander too. I watch it every Christmas. It's so big and sprawling and full of love and terror. It has everything.
Mulholland Drive. I've seen this movie probably forty times. I still don't totally understand it and that's what I love about it. Lynch creates a feeling that no other filmmaker can.
Seven Samurai -- I mean, what can you say. It's the greatest action movie ever made. Toshiro Mifune is unbelievable in this.
I'm going to grab Stalker. People are surprised when I pick Tarkovsky but I think comedy and art cinema come from the same place -- you're trying to get at something true.
Paris, Texas. Oh man, that scene in the peep show booth? Harry Dean Stanton and Nastassja Kinski? Devastating. Wim Wenders at his absolute best.
Night of the Hunter is maybe the scariest movie ever made. Robert Mitchum is terrifying. And it's so beautifully shot -- it looks like a fairy tale nightmare.
In the Mood for Love! I watched this for the first time last year and I was just wrecked. The restraint of it. They never consummate anything and that's what makes it so devastating.
Mulholland Drive changed my brain chemistry. I'm serious. After I watched it I couldn't stop thinking about it for like three weeks. Naomi Watts is incredible.
I'm going to take Persona. It's so bold and weird and it kind of broke my understanding of what a movie could be.
Oh, Mulholland Drive for sure. That Club Silencio scene? I think about it all the time. It's pure emotion through sound and image. Very inspiring for music.
Seven Samurai. I watched this with my boyfriend and it's just -- it's perfect. The pacing, the emotion, the action. Everything.
In the Mood for Love. The aesthetic of this film is just -- it's perfect pop. The colors, the dresses, the repetition. It's like a pop song that gets stuck in your head.
